summary: a genetic association study of DC-SIGNR in a well-characterized cohort of 197 HIV-infected mothers and their infants recruited in Harare, Zimbabwe. the implicated H1 and H3 haplotypes share two single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in promoter region (p-198A) and intron 2 (int2-180A) that were associated with increased risk of both IU and IP. disproportionately affecting the expression of membrane-bound isoforms compared to infant noncarriers. the rate of HIV-1 mother-to-child transmission is approximately 15–45%. MTCT of HIV-1 is responsible for one third of all deaths among children under the age of five. DC-SIGNR can internalize and mediate proteasome-dependant degradation of viruses that may differently affect the outcome of infection. a genetic association study of DC-SIGNR in a well-characterized cohort of HIV-infected mothers and infants recruited in Zimbabwe identified specific DC-SIGNR variants associated with increased risk of HIV transmission. samples were drawn from two groups: 97
